pageContent.copy: A fully responsive, dynamic platform capable of easily generating and managing thousands of pages for Twitter Marketing

pageContent.intro:
Twitter needed a solid front-end to go with their fancy new Adobe Experience Manager (AEM) enterprise backend.

The build needed to scale to fit thousands of pages, but be modern and fresh enough to fit the Twitter brand.

pageContent.copyLeft:
Our team built the module framework from the ground up using modern web technologes.

This took months of planning and had a ton of moving parts, but we had an awesome client and a talented team so we were confident we could deliver.
pageContent.copyRight:
The site took longer to build than expected but launched within a reasonable timeframe; Twitter has since scaled the framework out to hundreds of pages without issue.

This team is one of our favorite clients and we're proud of the work we did on this site.

pageContent.copy: Twitter's online global learning application for marketers and advertisers.

pageContent.intro:
Twitter's Flight School started as an e-learning tool for a very niche audience. It proved to be extremely successful, so it was expanded into multiple markets on a global scale.

The biggest challenge was updating the UI, Backend, etc without disrupting the constant daily users.

pageContent.copyLeft:
This project was built using the React framework, and we ran this with strict Agile sprints.

As the project scaled, multiple stakeholders became involved with differing priorities. Maintaining a strict Agile workflow, we were to prioritize the backlog.
pageContent.copyRight: In this way, the stakeholders were able to have visibility into the project timeline and work out prioritization amongst themselves while having full transparency into the project.

pageContent.copy: A multi-phase contest to find the most iconic residence in each district in France.

pageContent.intro:
Airbnb wanted to host a contest in France that would let users submit their unique Airbnb listings.

Judges narrowed down the submissions to three finalists in each region.

The public could then vote on their favorite listings in each of the 14 regions.

pageContent.copyLeft: We built a system that was secure enough to be accurate, but simple enough to keep people from dropping off before voting.
pageContent.copyRight: The contest received thousands of submissions. There were attempts at cheating the voting system but our backups were able to detect these cheating patterns quickly.

pageContent.copy: Helping to change how people use Airbnb when planning trips.

pageContent.intro: People think of Airbnb like a hotel-replacement, but it can be so much more. Road Trippers was one attempt at providing road trip ideas along classic routes. These routes just happen to have awesome Airbnb listings along the way.

pageContent.copyLeft:
We wanted the routes to connect attractions and nearby listings, so we couldn't rely on the Google Maps API to give us path coordinates.

Getting the coordinates was tricky. We ended up using a combination of Google Earth, Excel, and some code editor magic to gather the data we needed.
pageContent.copyRight:
We designed and built this project on an insanely-tight timeline.

Despite some last-minute listing changes, we launched it on time. The client was happy with what we were able to create.

pageContent.copy: Sharing a New Home for the Holidays in time for Thanksgiving.

pageContent.intro:
We got a call from our friend at Airbnb saying a project with an impossible timeline was coming, and that we were welcome to say no.

Challenge Accepted!

pageContent.copyLeft:
Airbnb wanted a shareable web app for Thanksgiving that people could use to share their holidays spent in an Airbnb.

Airbnb and Chiat/Day came up with the concept; Airbnb required Chiat to work with Martian because we knew how their deployment process worked.
pageContent.copyRight: We had less than 2 weeks to do UX, Design and Development. The app needed to grab camera/camera roll images, overlay one of a dozen filters on top, create a url and then be able to share the image on facebook/twitter, as well as be downloadable.

pageContent.copyLeft: We built the app to post to facebook via a link share. The app was mobile-only, but we realized that the shared content needed to be viewable on desktop to we had to build out some exceptions.
pageContent.copyRight: We launched the app in time for Thanksgiving; we were proud of what we were able to build in the time given.

pageContent.copy: building a new ux for a unique product.

pageContent.intro:
For years, Sony has been leading the pack in progressing the digital experience. Recently this innovation effort has resulted in a number of new, futuristic products such as the HMZ head-mounted display. The product has generated a lot of buzz and has been labeled as a serious competitor to the revolutionary Oculus Rift.

Selling the value of such a unique product required a web experience that would match the product's real-world product design. As the device is a video display, the creative team wanted to utilize some sort of video or motion sequence.

Sony's new site was built for modern browsers, and Sony wanted the showcase module experience to translate across desktop and mobile devices.

pageContent.copyLeft:
There were many different solutions to the problem; Video scrubbing, static image sequence traversing, and animation via time-codes were all attempted. Using html5, css3 and javascript, we tried many solutions and weighed the pros and cons of each.

Additionally, iPhones don't play video inline so we had to have an alternate technical implementation for that scenario.

A simple linear dragger wasn't novel enough so we tried different approaches to the animation. We settled on an arc motion to replicate a thumb swipe on a mobile device which felt very natural.
pageContent.copyRight:
The technique we settled on was a hybrid of static image sequences that could be toggled on and off in rapid succession, simulating motion. Then, we tied those sequences together with video clips for the transitions.

The result was a module that was as interesting as the product itself. The interactive integrity was maintained across all devices and screen sizes, and the module gracefully degraded for older browsers.

pageContent.copy: Thinknear: A site for a mobile-first technology company.

pageContent.intro: Thinknear's design team had desktop comps already; the comps were beautiful but image-heavy. Additionally, they ONLY had desktop comps.

pageContent.copyLeft: The client had a ton of content to display and needed an easy way to manage it. This was their first managed site so we chose Wordpress to manage the content.
pageContent.copyRight: The client was able to upload a TON of content to the site and manage it with very little support.. We were happy to find a happy medium between the friendliness of Wordpress' admin interface and a modern static site generator.

pageContent.copy: Using web technologies to build an innovative trade show screen solution.

pageContent.intro: Mede Analytics had a huge trade show and needed help standing out among the crowd. They rented a 15' jumbo-tron screen and mounted it above their booth; now they needed content to display. The client wanted to be able to type in messages in realtime and display them on the screen. They also wanted to be able to upload images. Additionally, they wanted to gather input from conference-goers and graph and display this data.

pageContent.copyLeft: We chose to use socket connections for realtime control of the screen. We knew that the browser could handle this type of interaction but weren't sure about 10 hours a day so we began testing immediately. We built different module types with different designs for each. We then created a programmable interface that would control the timing and content contained in the screens.
pageContent.copyRight: We built a mobile web app to gather the survey input; booth hosts would solict people to take the quiz throughout the event via iPads. The client would also share the quiz to their social channels so those not in attendance could also particpate. The application performed well and handled over one thousand survey responses, both from within the conference and via Twitter.

pageContent.copy: Twitter asked us to help build out their Video Marketing site. They wanted the site to feel modern and fresh, as well as showcase the new autoplay video functionality feature on Twitter.

pageContent.intro:
The site launch coincided with the feature launch happening on twitter.com, so our development process needed to be scalable in case the launch date was moved up.

Sure enough, the launch date was moved and we had to scale the team. Planning ahead allowed us to scale seamlessly and hit the new date.
